name: Ad Hominem
definition: Attacking the person making the argument rather than the argument itself.
whyItWorks: If we can make the person look bad, we feel okay ignoring what they said—even when their point is still good.

examples.text: You're just saying we should study together because you have no friends.
examples.analysis: Even if that insult were true, it doesn't answer whether studying together is actually a good idea.

examples.text: Of course she supports prison reform—she's never been a victim of violent crime.
examples.analysis: Her personal experience doesn't decide whether her arguments are good. The reasons and evidence matter, not her biography.

examples.text: Why would anyone listen to that influencer about nutrition? They're just a college dropout trying to sell supplements.
examples.analysis: Their background is worth knowing, but it doesn't automatically make each claim false. You still have to check the claim itself.

examples.text: You only think housing prices are too high because you're bitter you can't afford one.
examples.analysis: Someone's situation doesn't change whether the numbers on housing costs are right or wrong.

examples.text: She's criticizing cancel culture now, but she participated in pile-ons five years ago. Total hypocrite.
examples.analysis: Pointing out hypocrisy doesn't answer whether her current argument about cancel culture makes sense.

examples.text: Why listen to him about cancel culture? He's just an old boomer who doesn't get the internet.
examples.analysis: Age and tech fluency don't automatically make his points wrong. You still need to look at what he's actually saying.

examples.text: You can't take her views on political violence seriously—she's just a radical activist.
examples.analysis: Calling her an activist labels her, but it doesn't show what's wrong with her arguments about violence.

examples.text: You only care about immigration because you're scared of people who look different.
examples.analysis: Accusing someone of bad motives doesn't prove their specific claims about immigration are wrong.

examples.text: Of course you're against regulating influencers—you make money from sponsorships.
examples.analysis: Financial incentives might be relevant, but they don't automatically refute any particular point about regulation.

examples.text: Teachers who talk about the housing crisis just want excuses for their low pay.
examples.analysis: Questioning teachers' motives doesn't engage with their actual arguments about housing costs.

promptStarters: People who believe this are usually just ___ who ___.
Of course they'd say that—they're a ___.
You can't trust their opinion because they ___.
Easy for them to say when they've never ___.
They only think that because they're ___.
